data.message: How is Glass intrusive and creepy in ways that a society full of audio and video recording devices isn't?

Jeremy Wagner-Kaiser Next time you go meet a new person, hold up your smart phone with video recording while talking with them. See how long that conversation lasts and what that person's opinion of you is.

Brad Thompson And what of the many cameras that record you on a daily basis? Those don't bother you? They aren't "intrusive and creepy"? In what way is Glass DIFFERENT from them?

Please answer the question rather than a providing a meaningless pseudo-glib answer.

Jeremy Wagner-Kaiser If you can't entertain my pseudo-glib answer, than you are willingly skipping over that answer, which you seek. You are presupposing that the other devices aren't creepy or that I accept them, which I do not. However those other devices, which I actually sell and install, aren't nearly as connected to the Internet in a meaningful way of identifying you and linking to various data points to do whatever with a full suite of apps.  The other thing is, do you really want your picture taken and recorded with a pinhole camera lens that makes you look like a fat mutant? Those lenses are very unflattering. And what about the guy in the urinal next to you that looks over and takes a picture of your shame? And what about when you get your ass beat when you walk into a bar with them? By adopting and promoting this technology is just another step to a full crowdsourced self surveillance of society and deeper invasion into personal privacy. Not to mention making people look so stupid. When your butt crack pic ends up on Facebook when you bent over, I think you'll come around.

Jeremy Wagner-Kaiser  surveillance solutions and technology vendors would like people to regard their own and others' privacy as a meaningless pseudo-glib. Countless examples are out there. Fortunately, not all of us are so blind to agree.
